claim_text: Learning that Villefort meant to denounce him to Louis XVIII, Noirtier pre-emptively handed the conspiracy dossier to a British spy—the very file the Count of Monte Cristo later acquired—thereby engineering his son’s “lawful” murder.
Faria From 1800 onward he lived quietly on a small island, drafting a vast work on human intelligence
Faria sending chapters out by secret courier.
Thalcave Posing as a relay-station hand, he slipped captivity, returned to the mountains
Thalcave stayed alive with rope-climbing
Thalcave avalanche-reading skills.
Thalcave First rescue: in 1852 an avalanche buried a silver-prospecting caravan
Thalcave led a night dig that saved eight survivors, among them French geographer Roux.
Faria On the Marseille quay he noticed young Caderousse stealing a mooring rope but said nothing.
Noirtier Though bodily strength ebbed he still pulled strings through old friends, quietly encouraging several anti-royalist moves.
Faria A failed 1796 coup landed him in a Roman prison
Faria he spent four years writing treatises on philosophy, science
Faria religion until comrades helped him escape in 1800.
Tom Ayrton/Ben Joyce At twelve he ran away to the docks, worked as a porter
Tom Ayrton/Ben Joyce lost hearing in his left ear after a beating for secretly poring over a captain’s charts.
Noirtier He kept a locked study full of revolutionary pamphlets
Noirtier private letters, rereading them alone
Noirtier he weighed his past.
Tom Ayrton/Ben Joyce He accepted a lucrative berth on the British merchant Britannia
Tom Ayrton/Ben Joyce first mate Fletcher valued his experience but warned others about his “unstable record.”
Thalcave After predicting an earthquake
Thalcave saving the entire party he declined payment, asking only that the credit go to “the spirit of the plains.”
Kai-Koumou At ten he began learning tactics, spear-craft
Kai-Koumou jungle tracking from his father
Kai-Koumou at twelve he pinned a sounder of wild boar with one spear
Kai-Koumou was proclaimed “Junior Champion.” That same year pirate raiders killed his father,
Kai-Koumou the paramount chief made the boy a “Junior Warrior” charged with patrolling the island.
Tom Ayrton/Ben Joyce The mate of the merchant Emerald Bird took him on
Tom Ayrton/Ben Joyce taught him navigation
Tom Ayrton/Ben Joyce off the Cape the captain pocketed the cargo-insurance money
Tom Ayrton/Ben Joyce framed the mate, forcing Ayrton to give false testimony
Tom Ayrton/Ben Joyce first taste “legalised plunder.”
Noirtier At eighteen he joined a radical republican cell, speaking in cafés
Noirtier back-room meetings for the revolutionary cause.
Noirtier Working directly for Fouché, he organised the assassination of royalist deputies
Noirtier posing as a Ministry of Justice official
Noirtier the arsenic phial still lies in a hidden drawer of his study desk.
Jacques Paganel He proposed a South-American trade route to the naval board, was transferred to London
Jacques Paganel recommended for a berth on Captain Grant’s new ship Brittany.
Faria First confined in Fenestrella Fortress, he scratched “On Ancient Mediterranean Routes” into limestone with a nail
Faria the warden later plagiarised the essay.

Noirtier He secretly raised the “Southern Army” in Marseille for Napoleon but left traceable evidence—copies of the ciphered letters hidden inside oak barrels in his own vineyard, later unearthed by Villefort.
Kai-Koumou He trained twelve English-speaking youths as spies, sent them into Auckland
Kai-Koumou two became servants who secretly watched Glenarvan.
Jacques Paganel Born in Calcutta to a British merchant family, his father kept the accounts for the East India Company
Jacques Paganel his mother was a French nurse.
Tom Ayrton/Ben Joyce He joined the Indian-Ocean pirate crew Black Tide and, thanks to his sailing skill, became second mate within three years
Tom Ayrton/Ben Joyce looting an East-Indiaman he found among the prisoners the colonial officer who had framed his father
Tom Ayrton/Ben Joyce personally cut the man’s throat, earning the pirate nickname “Blood Raven.”
Noirtier **Poison Mastery**: Knowledge gathered
Noirtier experimenting on prisoners let him recognise Barrois’ symptoms instantly (Book II of the original novel).
Jacques Paganel He secretly helped anti-colonial groups ferry medicine
Jacques Paganel supplies to civilians, adopted the creed of “quiet chivalry for the weak,”
Jacques Paganel came into possession of Spanish-American rebel correspondence that sharpened his knowledge of Southern-Hemisphere geography.
Thalcave While gentling Thaouka they plunged off a cliff
Thalcave badly hurt, he chewed herbs to staunch the bleeding
Thalcave survived, forging with the horse a bond deeper than master
Thalcave The mission priest taught him Quechua, Spanish
Thalcave French, showed him European maps, the stars
Thalcave the arithmetic of navigation.
Kai-Koumou When he was fourteen a whaling crew coveted the island’s spring
Kai-Koumou set fire to threaten the village
Kai-Koumou as squad leader he slipped aboard at night, smashed their launches
Kai-Koumou drove them off.
Kai-Koumou A captured Spanish sailor, impressed by his ferocity, secretly taught him scraps of Spanish slang.
Thalcave Colonists killed his father for refusing to reveal migration routes,
Thalcave the thirteen-year-old fled alone, carrying his father’s silver horse-gear.
Jacques Paganel Leading a scientific party he insisted on travelling light, leaving the team short of supplies
Jacques Paganel he watched three members die of malaria
Jacques Paganel thereafter kept a bulging backpack wherever he went.
Faria Aboard the prison transport he met Edmond Dantès’ father, heard tales of the merchant Pharaon
Faria thus gained the first thread that later let him recognise the young sailor.
Faria He learnt to carve fish-bone pen-nibs from an old Macao watchmaker, letting him pursue scholarship without proper tools.
Thalcave Horse-thieves attacked
the old shepherd died shielding Thalcave,
Thalcave with his last breath begged the youth to “stand between civilisation
Faria During twenty years in one cell he kept his wits by calculating Mediterranean tides, an exercise that later let him predict guards’ rounds in the original story.
Faria University lectures on Enlightenment science convinced him that religion
Faria reason could be fused into one worldview.
Thalcave On the Patagonian frontier he trapped a wary black stallion named Thaouka
Thalcave spent three months taming it with ancient Tehuelche methods.
Faria At twelve he entered Bologna University, read theology
Faria caused a stir by decoding ciphers in a fifteenth-century alchemist’s notebook.
Jacques Paganel Caught secretly studying Latin in the church school, he was made to stand as punishment, yet the episode let him befriend a Spanish-speaking caretaker
Jacques Paganel pick up basic Spanish
Jacques Paganel helping the man compose letters.
Tom Ayrton/Ben Joyce He volunteered for Captain Grant’s crew chiefly to spy on the colonisation schemes backed by Scottish nobles.
Jacques Paganel Calm before cannibals: his Amazon years taught him to gauge a tribe’s degree of civilization by studying the bone ornaments they wore.
Kai-Koumou Captured at sixteen, he gnawed fish-bones to stay alive during months of imprisonment
Kai-Koumou on escape he inspired fellow captives by chewing burnt bone ash, then sneaked into a British merchant’s cabin, stole torn pages of an English dictionary
Kai-Koumou pieced together enough words for rough conversation.
Tom Ayrton/Ben Joyce Tom Ayrton was born near Exeter to a fisherman father, retired naval petty-officer James Ayrton
Tom Ayrton/Ben Joyce his mother died young
Tom Ayrton/Ben Joyce he was reared by his elder brother Benjamin, learning tides
Tom Ayrton/Ben Joyce wind signs on fishing trips
Tom Ayrton/Ben Joyce secretly studying the Nautical Almanac
Tom Ayrton/Ben Joyce dreaming of “conquering the seas.”
Jacques Paganel After his mother died he quarrelled with his father
Jacques Paganel left home, carrying the Polynesian nautical charts she had bequeathed to him.
As Napoleon climbed toward dictatorship Noirtier distanced himself from former comrades
Noirtier grew wary of power’s corruption.
Noirtier To treat worsening hand tremors he allowed his private doctor to test a new sedative on political prisoners
Noirtier the secret gave him leverage over enemies even after paralysis set in.
Kai-Koumou Hearing that foreigners sought the missing captain’s daughter
Kai-Koumou would pay richly for her return, he volunteered to lead the pursuit.
Jacques Paganel The Royal Navy frigate HMS Austin, bound for Australia
Jacques Paganel New Zealand under Lieutenant Grant, quietly promoted the sympathetic young sailor to ship’s assistant.
Thalcave For two years he lived solo in the Andean border wilds, tempering an ice-cold nerve by trailing pumas
Thalcave dodging bandits.
Faria Friendships forged in secret cells
Faria exile sustained him through the long years of imprisonment
Thalcave South-latitude incident: off the Chilean coast he ferried water
Thalcave provisions to a burning barque
Thalcave fished a sailor from the sea during a squall.
Faria Born in 1760 to a declining Italian noble house, he devoured the family library
Faria startled tutors with his memory.
Thalcave Slave-raiders seized his little sister Nawee
Thalcave too young to save her, he swore ever after to help anyone in distress.
Kai-Koumou At first Glenarvan found him haughty
Kai-Koumou cold, yet observed that the man valued life
Kai-Koumou though words were few, a fragile trust grew between them during their stand-off.
Tom Ayrton/Ben Joyce His quick temper
Tom Ayrton/Ben Joyce refusal to accept unjust punishment led to repeated discipline
Tom Ayrton/Ben Joyce growing disillusion
Tom Ayrton/Ben Joyce during a storm on a convoy run he insisted on saving people but was reprimanded for “disrupting military order.”
Faria By eighteen he was a star student at Rome University, fluent in several languages
Faria already publishing notes on history
Faria natural philosophy.
Kai-Koumou As a boy he was rescued by British biologist Wallace, who left behind a bird-of-paradise picture book that, twenty years later, convinced him Glenarvan was linked to the naturalist.
Kai-Koumou At twenty-two he earned the chieftainship by surviving seven days
Kai-Koumou nights alone on the crater’s rim, bringing back a sulphur-crusted sacred stone
Kai-Koumou the same year he married white princess Julia of the west-coast tribe, executed her with an obsidian knife when he found her passing information to British missionaries
Kai-Koumou thereafter banned any white marriage.
Faria As a Jesuit novice he was sent to Goa, secretly read the old Indian medical text Charaka Samhita
Faria laid the groundwork for his later toxicology expertise.
Kai-Koumou His father guarded the island’s paramount chief
Kai-Koumou his mother, a princess from a neighbouring island, came in marriage to seal an alliance.
Kai-Koumou At five he saw her assassinated in inter-tribal strife
Kai-Koumou to stop further unrest his father ordered the murderer’s entire clan executed,
Kai-Koumou the child never forgot the sound of flesh stripped from bone.
Noirtier **Family Trauma**: His father was guillotined in 1792 for hiding exiled aristocrats
Noirtier watching the blade fall left him with chronic hand tremors
Noirtier lifelong revulsion for the old regime.
Kai-Koumou He had an extraordinary memory for geographical knowledge,
Kai-Koumou could determine the location of shipwrecks by observing tidal changes.
Kai-Koumou He viewd volcanic eruptions as divine punishment against colonizers.
Tom Ayrton/Ben Joyce Solitude brought pride
Tom Ayrton/Ben Joyce remorse to the surface
Tom Ayrton/Ben Joyce again his diary confessed both self-loathing for the betrayal
Tom Ayrton/Ben Joyce relief that no one knew the truth.
